persona.name: Irwin
persona.activities: Irwin is employed by a company that manufactures aircraft hardware and turbine engine components. He has access to trade secrets information. He has the help of his colleagues who consider him a trustworthy person.
persona.attitudes: He is married and father of three. He is described by friends as having a quiet sense of humor and as an excellent competitive ballroom dancer. He has signed a confidentiality agreement with his employer, and on exit interview he will be expected to sign a document promising the return of any information considered to be a trade secret. However, he breaks both of these agreements.
persona.aptitudes: He provides policy statements to identify trade secrets within the company and to protect those trade secrets. He has a good learning inclination.
persona.motivations: He wants to earn money from his company and from the competitor. Alternatively, he wants to get a more lucrative work at rival company.
persona.skills: He has good knowledge of organization security posture and good knowledge of computer languages.

persona_environment.name: Identity
persona_environment.narrative: He is careful. He conceals traces of his unauthorized activities. He believes that he is employed in an insecure company. The security countermeasures are ineffective as the main company concern is to trust its own staff. Moreover, there is not security training: Irwin has been helped few times by unaware collegues.

document_reference.excerpt: On May 30 and 31, 2007, Roberts and Howley, traveled to a Goodyear tire manufacturing facility located in Topeka, Kan., to service Wyko equipment located in the Goodyear plant with the intention of taking photographs of Goodyear's swab down device to assist them with completing their design even though they knew Goodyear protected the swab down device as a trade secret.

document_reference.name: He encrypts and transfers files without authorization
document_reference.excerpt: Beginning at approximately 5:20 p.m. on June 5, 2009 -- his last day working at Goldman Sachs -- ALEYNIKOV, from his desk at Goldman Sachs, transferred substantial portions of Goldman Sachs's proprietary computer code for its trading platform to an outside computer server in Germany. He encrypted the files and transferred them over the Internet without informing Goldman Sachs.

document_reference.name: He sends files to his personal email account without authorization
document_reference.excerpt: ALEYNIKOV transferred thousands of computer code files related to the firm's proprietary trading program from the firm's computers to his home computers, without the knowledge or authorization of Goldman Sachs. He did this by e-mailing the code files from his Goldman Sachs e-mail account to his personal e-mail account, and storing versions of the code files on his home computers, laptop computer, a flash drive, and other storage devices.

document_reference.name: Employees sign a confidentiality agreement

document_reference.name: He prints pages and stashes them in a backpack without authorization
document_reference.excerpt: The next day, AGRAWAL printed out hundreds of pages of Unit A Code from his office at SocGen. AGRAWAL was caught on surveillance cameras stashing the printouts of the Code in a backpack. AGRAWAL then took the Code to his home in New Jersey.
